content.description: Located 15-20' right of Fred Sandstone Flake. Scramble up the lower slab with a couple of interesting moves to a ledge stance below a small roof and short headwall. Arrange pro from small wires and cams then pull onto the vertical face where a sequence of thin edge and flake moves leads past more clean, small protection to easier but still steep ground and a mantle onto the wide flat ledge at the top. Notable is that this climb's onsight first ascent was done at midnight under the light of a full moon, with the quite drunken f.a. party wearing headlamps- hence the name Werewolf. We were camping just down the hill below Bubba City and it was a beautiful night, so we said, "Let's go climbing!"
content.protection: This route's recommended rack is strictly small and medium wires and cams, with doubles on the smaller end of the range. 1 pin.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: Bubba City 'Beer Wall' area. Descend by rappel from any of the trees on top of the buttress.

content.description: Follow the obvious chimney system and wide roof crack to the top. The roof looks imposing but is surprisingly straight forward. Moving around the lip is the crux.
content.protection: bring one or two 5 or 6 inch pieces for under the roof, a 4 inch for the lip and a standard rack for the rest.

content.description: Thin start to sustained 10a climbing, crux in a crack below small roof.
content.location: 15' right of Spatenweiss.  Bolt line up steep orange face.

content.description:
similar to St. Pauli Girl, but a bit more stout. Follow the bolt line just right of Micro Brew through two roofs until it joins with St. Pauli Girl at its last bolt.

(description from Mike William's guidebook)
content.location: in between Micro Brew and St Pauli Girl

climbs.name: Near Beer
climbs.fa: Charles Ganote, Cindy Hintz. Eric Hörst, Eric McCallister (June, 2002)

content.description:
Hard for 5.6 !  Awkward move exiting the alcove and overhang.

Work your way up some broken rock for a few moves, then go right above the first bolt to a stance.  Continue straight up past a small overhang (crux), then go left to the obvious flake and wide crack.  Follow flake and crack to the anchors.
content.location: On a small ledge on a small southwest-facing portion of the cliff, about 12 feet left of Gilded Otter where the trail descends a bit.

climbs.name: My Sister Makes Cluster Bombs
climbs.fa: Eric Horst, Rick Thompson, Bob Rentka

content.description:
The  initial blast is powerful, but don't let your guard down on the moves above. Fortunately you can fully rest up on the ledge before engaging the small, crescent-shaped corner

(description from Mike William's guidebook)
content.location: it is the second bolt line after the air conditioned chimney. Daisy Cutter is left line of bolts.

content.description:
Not as good as Gilded Otter.  Has some broken rock and is a bit contrived in that the finish is the same as Gilded Otter.  Essentially bypasses the crux bulge of that climb.

Climb the flake and corner systemn past 2 bolts, then continue up and left in the corner system clipping the final 3 bolts of Gilded Otter.
content.location: On a southeast-facing small section of sliff that juts from the main cliff, just past where the trail descends a bit below an obvious right-facing flake.

content.description:
Better than Near Beer.

Climb the open book (easier than it looks), then past a bulge (crux, tough clip for 5.7 leader) to a ledge.  Mantle onto ledge and finish through roof (easy) to the anchors.
content.location: On a short south-facing section of rock that juts out from the main cliff, just past where the trail descends a bit.

climbs.name: Fred Sandstone Flake
climbs.fa: Dan Caldwell, Mark Pell, Jon Regelgrugge

content.description: Climb a slab to a more vertical lighter-colored face. Stay left, near the arete and pull the roof at the left facing corner. Finish up a ramp to anchor.
content.protection: Takes plenty of tcus and cams smaller than #1 for the first half and nuts for the flake.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: This is the left-most route on the face left of the long hallway-like cave at Beer Wall.

content.description: Climb slab to a ledge. Climb toward alcove but avoid going in; stay left passing a small tree. Follow cracks to a ledge and top out.
content.protection: Sling anchor around a pine tree.
content.location: In the right corner of the face that is left of the hallway-like cave.

content.description: Pull the roof and continue to anchors on thin holds.
content.location: Start on right side of high roof, 5' right of Cirrhosis of the Leader.

content.description: This route begins in a chimney..crosses over an awkward (creepy) gap to a large flake...then up less than vertical rock to the top. Can be pretty committing for the 5.7 leader.

Start on the left side of a face under a high roof.  Climb the steep bouldery moves trending up and right through overhangs passing the 2 bolts to reach the shuts.  All moves are protected extremely well.  Short and powerful.  Although this is short, it's well worth doing, especially on a rainy day.  The guidebook rates it 5.11d/5.12a so its a great route if you are just breaking into the 5.12 grade.
content.location: This is the first route to the right of Celebration Ale.  Locate the large, high roof at the end of the beer wall.

content.description:
This is a fun, balancy face climb on good rock.

Make a move or two, then step right to the first bolt.  Continue up the thin and fun face to a small bulge.  Surmount bulge on big holds, then up to a small ledge and the anchors.
content.location: At a gray face where the trail descends below a large roof system, below the left edge of said roof system.  Look for the nice white face.

content.description: It shares the start with Cerveza Verde. Clip the first bolt of Cerveza Verde, then do a balancy traverse towards the right to the second bolt. Follow the this right bolt line to a stance beneath the cap roof. move left over the roof on small, awkward crimps to one last clip before the anchors.
content.location: In between Cerveza Verde and Cirrhosis of the leader.

content.description: Begins with thin moves off the deck on lousy feet.  Stick clipping the first bolt is a great idea.  Clip the 2nd bolt, then begin wandering a bit up through the next few clips until you pull through a couple of fun roofs.  Stab over the lip for a blind sinker hold at roof #1, then get a good hand jam rest at #2.  Pull over on some marginal holds and clip the anchors.
content.location: Located immediately to the the right (upstream) of St. Pauli Girl.  The obvious roofs and blank beginning will identify it.

climbs.name: Beer Wench
climbs.fa: Eric McCallister, Eric Hörst, Charles Ganote, and Cindy Hintz (June, 2002)

content.description:
No way this puppy is 5.8- (the original rating).  Definite sandbag.  The opening crack is at least 5.9.  Get a good spot or bring a stick clip for the crux, because you'll be doing it before you clip the first bolt.

Climb the flaring crack through the bulge (crux, strenuous clip), then stray a bit right up the nice face to a short open book.  Stem up the open book (5.7) to the anchors.
content.location: Below an obvious flaring crack below the far right side of the roof system.

content.description: Start on the face below the left end of a ledge and climb directly up past a pin to reach it, step right and pull the small roof/bulge under the v-shaped block (crux). Follow an open-book/crack system to the top, traversing left under the roof to top out.
content.protection: The pin may now be gone, I didn't see it as of July, 07, No bolts at the top but a good tree is several feet from the lip. Protects well with a standard rack.
content.location: 20 feet left of the obvious Bubbafied chimney and roof system. Please bring your second up and use the existing rappel tree or the bolts on top of Werewolf or Daisycutter
